bibl.title: Despatch from Samuel S. Sevier to Thomas F. Bayard
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

div1.p:
Mr S. S. Sevier
To Secretary of State

Hon. T. F. Bayard
Secretary of State
Washington D.C.

I have the honor to refer you to my despatch No. 48 of which I sometime wrote in regard to the trouble at Cavalla. Since then the trouble has not quailed. Spirit of disloyalty and rebellion is at work. The civilized christian native and many of the Americo-Liberian have been forced
forced from their homes to subject on the kindness of their friends or starve. His excellency President H. R. W. Johnson of this Republic has not as yet taken any steps to arest the spirit of rebellion. Further information will be given to the Department of State whenever steps are taken to arest the present trouble.

I have the honor to be,
Sir,
Your obedient Servant
Sam'l S. Sevier
U.S. Vice Consul Genl.

div2.p: "Therefore as ye abound in every thing, in faith, in utterance, and knowledge, and in all diligence, and in your love see that you abound in this grace also."
"For ye know the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ, that, though he was rich yet for our sakes he became poor that through his poverty ye might be rich."
"If there be first a willing mind, it is accepted according to that a man hath, and not according to that he hath not" II Cor. VIII.

"He that soweth sparingly shall reap also sparingly, and he which soweth bountifully shall reap also bountifully. Every man according as he purposeth in his heart, so let him give; not grudgingly, or of necessity for God loveth a cheerfun giver." II Cor. IX.

div2.head: To the Monrovia Public:
div2.p: There is trouble at Cavalla; spirit of disloyalty and rebellion is at work. Because the civilized and christian natives did not sympathize, with this feeling, they were forced to leave their homes and relations to save their lives, and flee to Harper, Cape Palmas. Leaving their farms and employments they are deprived of the means of support, and are dependent upon christian help until they can help themselves.

The people at Cape Palmas, have done, and are doing all in their power for the comfort of the refugees. This appeal comes to you now. What will you do? Out of your abundance will you give much, and out of your poverty give a little? Every little will be a help. Let not the benevolent hard working poor fail to give because they have but a little: but of that little give something.

Every thing is needed, food, raiment, household articles &c: the sufferers number between forty and fifty men, women and children. Show your liberality towards your brethren and sisters of this native church, the church of the Epiphany at Cavalla. Right Rev. Bishop Ferguson will gladly bear to them your christian gifts.
